metadata.description: Sales rep training quiz with heavy focus on financing knowledge

categories.name: Financing Basics
categories.description: Core knowledge about payment options and fees

questions.question: What is the origination fee for Split It financing?
questions.explanation: Split It has a 15% origination fee with 0% APR. This fee is standard across Split It, Elective, and Klarna.

questions.question: Which financing option has NO origination fee?
questions.explanation: Payva has no initiation fee - they charge a fixed APR instead. Coach Financing also has no initiation fee.

questions.question: What is the APR for Split It financing?
questions.explanation: Split It offers 0% APR - no interest! The only cost is the 15% origination fee.

questions.question: What is the maximum term length for Klarna?
questions.explanation: Klarna offers up to 24 months, making it great for clients who need longer terms than the typical 12-month options.

questions.question: What is the maximum term length for Coach Financing?
questions.explanation: Coach Financing offers up to 144 months (12 years!), making it the longest-term option available for keeping monthly payments extremely low.

questions.question: Which card type is required for Split It?
questions.explanation: Split It requires a PERSONAL credit card - no business cards allowed. It places a hold on the card for the full amount.

questions.question: How does Split It work with the credit card hold?
options: Places hold for full amount, charges monthly
questions.explanation: Split It places a HOLD on the card for the full amount but only CHARGES the monthly installment. The hold reduces as the balance is paid down.

questions.question: Which THREE financing options have a 15% origination fee?
questions.explanation: Split It, Elective, and Klarna all have a 15% origination fee. Payva and Coach have no initiation fee.

questions.question: What type of payment method does Klarna require for the first payment?
questions.explanation: Klarna requires a DEBIT card for the first payment - credit cards won't work for the initial payment.

questions.question: What does PIF stand for?
questions.explanation: PIF stands for Pay In Full - the standard full payment option with no financing fees.

questions.question: Which financing option will approve ANYONE regardless of credit?
questions.explanation: Payva approves anyone regardless of credit score. It's the go-to option for clients with bad or no credit.

questions.question: California residents are NOT eligible for which financing option?
questions.explanation: California residents cannot use Elective due to state regulations. Recommend Klarna or Payva instead.

questions.question: What is the IDEAL credit score for Elective financing?
questions.explanation: Elective ideally requires 650+ credit score, though they CAN approve down to 550.

questions.question: What is the minimum credit score Elective can approve?
questions.explanation: Elective can approve down to 550 credit score, though 650+ is ideal for the best terms.

questions.question: What credit score is required for Klarna?
questions.explanation: Klarna requires a 600+ credit score. For clients below 600, recommend Payva or Coach instead.

questions.question: Which financing options are available for Canadian residents?
questions.explanation: Canadian residents can use Elective and Payva. Klarna and Coach are US only.

questions.question: For Payva, what happens with clients who have a 600+ credit score?
questions.explanation: With Payva, clients with 600+ credit are FUNDED upfront. Below 600, payments are collected monthly (Servicing model).

questions.question: A Canadian resident with a 580 credit score wants financing. What's their ONLY option?
questions.explanation: For a Canadian with low credit: Elective requires 550+ (possible), Klarna is US only, Coach is US only. Payva Servicing works for anyone including Canadians.

questions.question: Which financing options are US ONLY?
questions.explanation: Klarna and Coach are both US only. Elective and Payva are available for Canadian residents.

questions.question: Does Split It affect the client's credit score?
options: Yes, it's a hard credit check
questions.explanation: Split It does NOT affect credit score at all - it uses the credit card hold system instead of a credit check.

questions.question: A client says 'I have good credit but I'm in California.' What financing do you recommend?
questions.explanation: California residents can't use Elective. For good credit, recommend Klarna (up to 24 months). If that doesn't work, Payva approves anyone.

questions.question: Client has 700 credit score and wants the lowest monthly payment. What's the best option?
questions.explanation: For the absolute lowest monthly payment, Coach Financing at 144 months beats everything, even with a personal loan APR. Good credit helps get better rates.

questions.question: Client says they've been declined for financing before and have bad credit. Best option?
questions.explanation: Payva approves ANYONE regardless of credit, and Coach works well for bad credit with extended terms. These are your go-to options for declined clients.

questions.question: Client has 620 credit and needs 18+ months. What's the recommended order?
questions.explanation: 620 credit is above Klarna's 600 minimum and they offer 24 months. If that fails, Payva approves anyone. Coach is last resort for longest terms.

questions.question: What's the recommended financing order for HIGH credit (650+)?
questions.explanation: For 650+ credit: Start with Elective (best terms), then Klarna if they need 18+ months, then Payva as backup.

questions.question: What's the recommended financing order for LOW credit (below 600)?
questions.explanation: For below 600 credit: Payva approves anyone, and Coach offers extended terms if needed. These are the only viable options.

questions.question: Client wants to protect their credit score AND get monthly payments. Best option?
questions.explanation: Split It doesn't affect credit score at all - no credit check, just a hold on their personal credit card. Perfect for credit-conscious clients.

questions.question: Client can put down 50% today and wants to finance the rest. What should you tell them?
options: They have to finance the full amount
The 15% fee applies to the full amount
The 15% fee only applies to the financed amount
questions.explanation: Clients can make a partial payment and finance the remainder - the 15% fee ONLY applies to the financed portion! This is a great way to reduce total cost.

questions.question: Client has good credit but Elective didn't offer 18 months. What's the next step?
options: Tell them 12 months is the only option
questions.explanation: If Elective doesn't offer the needed terms (like 18 months) and the client can't make 12 months work, move to Klarna which offers up to 24 months.

questions.question: What creative option lets a client use multiple financing sources?
questions.explanation: Clients can use MULTIPLE finance options - for example, half on Elective and half on Payva. This flexibility helps close deals.

questions.question: Client says 'I can't afford it.' What's the first question to ask?
options: Do you roughly know what your credit score is?
Would you like a smaller package?
questions.explanation: Always ask about credit score first - it determines which financing options you can offer. This opens the door to multiple payment solutions.

questions.question: Client says 'I have bad credit.' What's your response?
options: You'll need to pay in full
No worries - Payva approves anyone, and Coach offers extended terms
questions.explanation: Never give up on bad credit clients! Payva approves ANYONE regardless of credit, and Coach offers up to 144 months to keep payments low.

questions.question: Client says 'The monthly payments are too high.' Best response?
options: That's the best we can do
We can extend terms with Klarna (24mo) or Coach (144mo)
Try paying in full to avoid fees
questions.explanation: Extend the terms! Klarna offers 24 months vs the typical 12, and Coach can go up to 144 months for the lowest possible monthly payments.

questions.question: Client says 'I don't want to do a credit check.' What options can you offer?
questions.explanation: Split It doesn't do a credit check - it just places a hold on their personal credit card. PIF obviously has no check either.

questions.question: Client says 'I need to talk to my spouse about the money.' How does financing help?
options: It doesn't - they still need to discuss it
Lower monthly payments make the conversation easier
questions.explanation: Financing makes the money conversation easier! Instead of discussing a large lump sum, they can discuss manageable monthly payments.

questions.question: Client says 'I was declined by another financing company.' What now?
options: They probably can't get financing here either
Payva approves anyone - Coach is the backup
They need to pay in full
Suggest they wait and try later
questions.explanation: Previous declines don't matter for Payva - they approve ANYONE. Coach Financing is also great for previously declined clients.

questions.question: Client asks 'What if I want to pay it off early?' What do you tell them?
options: They can pay off anytime with no penalty
questions.explanation: There are no early payoff penalties - clients can pay off their balance anytime they want without extra fees.

questions.question: What's the discovery question to ask before recommending financing?
options: How much can you afford monthly?
Do you roughly know what your credit score is?
Do you have a credit card?
questions.explanation: Always ask: 'Do you roughly know what your credit score is?' This determines which financing options to recommend.

questions.question: Client says 'I don't want to pay any fees or interest.' What's their only option?
questions.explanation: PIF (Pay In Full) is the ONLY option with zero fees and zero interest. All financing options have either fees or APR.

questions.question: Client says 'The 15% fee seems high.' Best response?
options: Frame it: '15% to start your business today vs waiting and possibly never starting'
questions.explanation: Reframe the fee as an investment in starting NOW. The cost of waiting (never starting, missing opportunities) is often higher than 15%.

questions.question: How does Payva's 'Servicing' model work for clients below 600 credit?
options: Payments are collected monthly (not funded upfront)
questions.explanation: For clients below 600 credit, Payva uses 'Servicing' mode where payments are collected monthly rather than the company being funded upfront.

questions.question: What's special about Coach Financing compared to other options?
options: It's a personal loan extending past 24 months
questions.explanation: Coach Financing is a personal loan that can extend to 144 months (12 years!). Once funded, you receive the PIF price - no origination fee.

questions.question: PayPal's 'Pay in 4' has what special benefit?
options: Soft credit check - no impact on score
questions.explanation: PayPal Pay in 4 does a SOFT credit check that doesn't impact the credit score. It's 0% APR, 4 payments over 2 weeks, for $30-$1,500.

questions.question: What's the APR range for PayPal Pay Monthly?
questions.explanation: PayPal Pay Monthly ranges from 9.99% to 35.99% APR, for amounts $149-$10,000, with 3-24 month fixed payment terms.

questions.question: What 'last resort' creative options exist when all financing fails?
options: Crypto, stocks, 0% APR card, 401K loan, family/friends
questions.explanation: Creative last resorts include: crypto, stocks, applying for a 0% APR credit card, 401K loan, and asking family/friends. Get creative!

questions.question: Why might Klarna be 'clunky' for some clients?
options: The process can be confusing for tech-challenged clients
It takes too long to approve
questions.explanation: Klarna's process can be clunky and confusing for tech-challenged clients. Keep this in mind when recommending to less tech-savvy prospects.

questions.question: What's the term range for PayPal Pay Monthly?
questions.explanation: PayPal Pay Monthly offers 3-24 month terms with fixed payments, competing with Klarna for longer-term financing.

questions.question: PayPal Credit offers what unique benefit for purchases over $99?
options: 6 months no interest if paid in full
questions.explanation: PayPal Credit offers 6 months no interest on purchases $99+ IF paid in full within that period. It's a revolving credit line.

questions.question: When using multiple cards/financing, what creative option exists?
questions.explanation: Clients can split payments across multiple cards AND combine with financing. For example, pay part on one card, finance the rest.

questions.question: What determines if Elective offers 0% APR?
questions.explanation: Elective offers 0% APR for clients with 'good finances' - a combination of credit score and overall financial health, not just credit score alone.

questions.question: Client is in Canada with 550 credit and needs 24 months. What's their path?
questions.explanation: For a Canadian with 550 credit: Elective requires 550+ but max 12 months, Klarna/Coach are US only. Payva Servicing is their only path, though terms max at 12 months.

questions.question: What payment method can be used for Elective's first payment?
questions.explanation: Elective accepts credit OR debit card for the first payment or down payment - unlike Klarna which requires debit only.

questions.question: Which financing option is described as a 'niche use case'?
questions.explanation: PayPal is considered a niche use case - only use it if you're comfortable walking the client through the various options.

questions.question: Client has 680 credit but only has a business credit card. What financing works?
questions.explanation: Split It requires a PERSONAL credit card. But Elective, Klarna, and Payva all work with any payment method for subsequent payments.

questions.question: Client says 'I've never financed anything and I'm scared to start.' Best approach?
options: Explain Split It doesn't affect credit and they stay in control
Tell them to pay in full then
questions.explanation: Split It is perfect for financing-nervous clients: no credit check, no impact on credit score, they stay in control with their own card.

questions.question: According to Eric's WFS framework, what's the first phase of a sales call?
questions.explanation: Building rapport comes first - establish connection and trust before moving into qualification and the rest of the call.

questions.question: What's the 'Three-Path Question' technique used for?
questions.explanation: The Three-Path Question gives prospects three options to choose from, making them feel in control while steering toward a decision.

questions.question: When a prospect says they're a '7 out of 10' serious about starting, what should you do?
options: Ask what would make them a 10
questions.explanation: Ask what would make them a 10 - this uncovers their remaining concerns and shows you what needs to be addressed to close.

questions.question: What's the scale question to gauge commitment?
options: Are you ready to buy today?
On a scale of 1-10, how serious are you about starting a vending business in the next 90 days?
questions.explanation: The scale question gauges commitment: 'On a scale of 1-10, how serious are you about starting a vending business in the next 90 days?'

questions.question: What follow-up question helps isolate the real objection?
options: If we could solve that, would you be ready to move forward today?
When would be a good time to call back?
questions.explanation: 'If we could solve that, would you be ready to move forward today?' isolates whether their stated objection is real or if there's something else.

questions.question: What's the first step when handling any objection?
questions.explanation: Always acknowledge and validate first - show them you heard and understand. Then move to addressing the objection.

questions.question: When someone says 'I need to think about it,' what's really happening?
questions.explanation: 'I need to think about it' almost always means there's an unspoken objection. Dig deeper to find the real concern.

questions.question: How should you respond to 'I need to talk to my spouse'?
options: Tell them to call back when they've talked
Ask what specifically they need to discuss
Schedule a call with both of them
All of the above could work, depending on context
questions.explanation: Multiple approaches work: understand what needs discussing, offer to have a call with both, or help them prepare for the conversation.

questions.question: What's the 'feel, felt, found' technique?
options: Empathy pattern: 'I understand how you feel, others felt the same, what they found was...'
questions.explanation: Feel, Felt, Found: 'I understand how you feel, many others felt the same way, what they found was...' - validates then provides social proof.

questions.question: When a prospect mentions a competitor, what should you do?
questions.explanation: Never bash competitors. Acknowledge they're doing research (good!), then differentiate on value - what makes your offering unique.

questions.question: What is the typical package range offered?
questions.explanation: Packages typically range from Bronze through Diamond, offering different levels of support, machines, and features.

questions.question: What emotional trigger works best for someone unhappy with their 9-5 job?
questions.explanation: For someone unhappy at work, all these triggers work: financial freedom, being their own boss, escaping the corporate grind.

questions.question: What's a 'win signal' that indicates you should move to close?
options: When they ask about payment options
When they say 'if I did this...'
questions.explanation: All of these are win signals! Payment questions, implementation discussions, and 'if I did this' language all show they're visualizing ownership.

questions.question: Client asks about Bronze package financing. Which option do you highlight?
options: PIF only - Bronze should be affordable
questions.explanation: Klarna is noted as 'good for lower packages (Bronze)' - it offers reasonable terms that work well for smaller amounts.

questions.question: Client says 'I have the money but don't want to drain my savings.' Best option?
options: Tell them to use savings anyway
Suggest financing to preserve their capital
Schedule follow-up when they've saved more
questions.explanation: Financing preserves capital! They can keep their savings for emergencies or investing in their business while making manageable payments.

questions.question: A client qualifies for multiple options. What's the PRIMARY factor in your recommendation?
options: Match their specific needs (term length, monthly budget, credit concerns)
questions.explanation: Always match the option to THEIR needs: term length they want, monthly budget, credit score concerns, etc. One size doesn't fit all.

questions.question: What's the term range for Elective financing?
questions.explanation: Elective offers 3-12 month repayment terms. For longer terms, clients need Klarna (24mo) or Coach (144mo).

questions.question: Client has 640 credit and lives in California. What's your financing order?
questions.explanation: California = no Elective. 640 credit = Klarna works (600+ required). Order: Klarna (best terms for their credit), then Payva, then Coach.

questions.question: Client says 'What's the catch with Payva approving everyone?' How do you respond?
options: The 'catch' is they charge APR instead of flat fee
questions.explanation: Payva's model: no initiation fee, but they charge fixed APR. That's how they can approve everyone - they adjust APR to risk level.

questions.question: Which payment options can use EITHER credit OR debit cards?
questions.explanation: Payva accepts credit or debit, and Elective accepts credit or debit for first/down payment. Split It needs personal credit card, Klarna needs debit for first.

questions.question: Client says they applied for a 0% APR credit card. What's a good play?
options: Wait for them to get the card
Have them PIF when the card arrives
This is a creative last resort option - support them
questions.explanation: Applying for a 0% APR card is actually listed as a creative last resort option! Support this approach - they can PIF with no financing cost.

questions.question: What often causes 'lost deals' that could have been saved?
options: Rep gave up too soon on objections
questions.explanation: Many deals are lost because reps give up too soon. Persistence and creative problem-solving (like multiple financing options) save deals.

questions.question: What credit tier is considered 'Fair Credit'?
questions.explanation: Fair Credit is 600-650. Above 650 is Good Credit, below 600 is Limited Credit with fewer options.

questions.question: Client with 700 credit wants ZERO interest. What's the best option?
options: There's no true 0% option besides PIF
questions.explanation: If they want truly ZERO interest and fees, PIF is the only option. Split It is 0% APR but has 15% fee. Elective has 15% fee too.

questions.question: Why is Coach Financing described as 'PIF price once funded'?
options: No origination fee - you receive full amount without fee reduction
questions.explanation: Coach has NO initiation fee, so once the loan is funded, you receive the full PIF price - unlike options that deduct 15% for fees.

questions.question: What keyword should trigger your financing recommendation?
questions.explanation: 'Can't afford' or similar (too expensive, don't have the money, budget) should immediately trigger your financing options pitch.

questions.question: How many financing partners are available?
questions.explanation: There are 7 payment options: PIF, Split It, Elective, Payva, Klarna, Coach, and PayPal.

questions.question: Client wants to put $2,000 down on a $10,000 package. The 15% fee applies to?
questions.explanation: The 15% fee ONLY applies to the financed amount ($8,000), not the full price. This is a great way to reduce total financing cost!

questions.question: Canadian resident with 700 credit wants maximum term length. What's available?
questions.explanation: For Canadians: Klarna and Coach are US only. Max term is Elective or Payva at 12 months. Elective is better for 700 credit.

questions.question: What's the purpose of asking about their current job?
options: To judge if they can afford it
To find their 'superpowers' that transfer to vending
questions.explanation: Job information helps you identify their 'superpowers' - transferable skills that make them perfect for vending success.

questions.question: Client says 'My friend did vending and failed, so I'm worried about financing.' Response?
options: Acknowledge, ask what went wrong, show how we're different
Suggest they pay in full to reduce risk
questions.explanation: Acknowledge their concern, probe what went wrong with the friend, then differentiate how our program/support prevents those issues.

questions.question: Which financing option would you recommend for someone who says 'I don't care about monthly amount, just longest terms'?
questions.explanation: Coach Financing offers the longest terms at up to 144 months (12 years!) - perfect for clients focused on term length.

questions.question: Which options have VARIABLE APR based on client qualifications?
questions.explanation: Elective (0% if good finances, varies otherwise), Payva (fixed APR based on profile), and Klarna (varies) all have variable APR.

questions.question: What makes PayPal a 'niche use case' according to the guidance?
options: Only use if rep is comfortable walking client through options
questions.explanation: PayPal has multiple options (Pay in 4, Pay Monthly, Credit) that can be confusing. Only recommend if YOU are comfortable explaining it all.

questions.question: Client wants financing but is worried about application rejection affecting their credit. Best recommendation?
options: Split It - no credit check at all
PayPal Pay in 4 - soft check, no score impact
Both A and C would work
questions.explanation: Both Split It (no credit check) and PayPal Pay in 4 (soft check, no impact) work for credit-concerned clients.

questions.question: When is it appropriate to mention 'testimonials' during objection handling?
options: When they need social proof that others succeeded
questions.explanation: Testimonials provide powerful social proof. Use them when prospects need to see that others like them have succeeded.

questions.question: Which financing option is best for someone who says 'I have excellent credit'?
options: Elective - best terms for good credit
questions.explanation: Elective is ideal for 650+ credit - they get the best terms, potentially 0% APR, and it's the primary recommendation for good credit.

questions.question: Client says 'I tried Elective but they only offered 9 months, I need 12.' What now?
options: Tell them 9 months is what they got
Try Klarna for potentially better terms
See if larger down payment gets better terms
Both B and C are good options
questions.explanation: Try Klarna which might offer different terms. Also, a larger down payment reduces financed amount which might get better terms. Both are worth trying.

questions.question: What's unique about how Split It handles monthly payments?
options: Hold on card, only charge monthly amount
questions.explanation: Split It places a HOLD on the credit card for the full amount but only CHARGES the monthly installment. The hold decreases as balance is paid.

questions.question: Client says 'I'll wait until I have the cash.' Best response approach?
options: Ok, call us back when ready
Explore the cost of waiting - opportunities missed, prices may increase
questions.explanation: Explore the cost of waiting - what opportunities will they miss? Will prices go up? Sometimes financing NOW costs less than waiting.

questions.question: What's the practical difference between Payva 'Funded' vs 'Servicing' mode?
options: You get money upfront vs collected monthly
questions.explanation: Funded (600+ credit): company receives money upfront. Servicing (below 600): payments are collected monthly and passed through.

questions.question: What's more important: handling the objection or understanding WHY they have it?
options: Understanding the real reason behind it
questions.explanation: Understanding WHY they have the objection is more important - it reveals the real issue. Often the stated objection isn't the real one.

questions.question: Client qualifies for everything. They say 'just tell me the best one.' How do you respond?
options: Ask clarifying questions about their priorities
List all options and let them choose
questions.explanation: Ask clarifying questions: What's more important - lowest monthly payment, shortest term, or lowest total cost? Then match accordingly.

questions.question: Client says 'I want to start but not with debt hanging over me.' How do you reframe?
options: It's not debt, it's an investment
The business will pay for itself
Frame monthly payment as business expense, like rent
All of these reframes can work
questions.explanation: All these reframes help: investment not debt, business pays for itself, monthly payment as operating expense. Pick what resonates with them.

questions.question: Why might you recommend AGAINST the lowest monthly payment option?
options: Longer terms = more total interest paid over time
questions.explanation: Longer terms mean more total interest. A client who CAN afford higher payments might want to pay less overall by choosing shorter terms.
